newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: FCC CUT SHOULD NOT HIT EARNINGS - SINGTEL.
newsitem.headline: FCC CUT SHOULD NOT HIT EARNINGS - SINGTEL.

text.p: The U.S. Federal communications Commission's (FCC) adoption of a lower charges for international telephone calls should not hurt Singapore Telecommunications Ltd (SingTel) earnings, the daily Business Times said on Saturday.

SingTel told the newspaper its existing arrangement with U.S. phone operators was at a low level and international moves to bring down so-called accounting rates would even out the FCC move over the long term.

"As a net out-payer, the lowering of settlement rates may not necessarily be a disadvantageous development to us in the long run when settlement rates are lowered on a multi-lateral basis," SingTel was reported as saying.
SingTel typically receives US$0.45 a minute for its part in completing calls originating in the U.S. Under the FCC plan this would be slashed to US$0.15, the paper said.

The company was responding to Thursday's FCC decision to set lower benchmarks on its international call rates and allow U.S. carriers to negotiate with foreign counterparts fixed reductions on charges by a specified period.

Accounting rates are used to decide how much telephone companies pay each other for international calls. They were designed to compensate phone companies in recipient countries for the cost of completing calls.
